reviewText:
Birds have a long history in gaming, dating back to the mascot wars of the 90s. Games like Sonic the Hedgehog, Spyro the Dragon, and Crash Bandicoot all brought birds to the forefront of gaming entertainment with their colorful bird protagonists, hinting at a bright future for avian kind. But as console generations came and went, the medium's focus shifted, and birds were all but lost in the gaming spectrum. Thankfully, all is not lost, and thanks to sleeper hits like Hatoful Boyfriend and Penguins Arena and the popular Tropes vs. Birds video series by Tweeta Parakeetian, birds are back, and better than ever - which brings us to the latest in bird entertainment, Aviary Attorney.

Avian Attorney is, as it says in the title, a game about birds practicing in the school of law - unlike its bird of a feather, Hatoful Boyfriend (which held its surprise so close to its plumage that even today most people still think it's a joke game about dating birds), this time it's just you, the birds, and the mysteries within. While it's not necessarily an original idea, predated by famous bird lawyer series Harvey Birdman: Attorney at Law more than a decade ago, it provides a fresh perspective through its unique presentation, in both its art style and music.

In terms of gameplay, Aviary Attorney will probably come as second nature to anyone familiar with the similarly named Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney series (which, despite its misleading title, is not about mystical birds). It's a visual novel with mystery elements, in which you travel between various locations gathering evidence leading up to a court trial. Unlike Phoenix Wright, however, travelling between most locations takes a day of your time, and you only have a certain amount of time before each court session begins, making you think more about where you need to go. There are four cases, with minor choices throughout the cases that lend to replayability (and frequently leave you wondering whether or not you've made a mistake), and the fourth case has 3 varients which are vary significantly both in story and length, and altogether the game lasted me around 7 hours. There are occasional bugs here and there, but the developer seems to be working hard to iron out the problems and in the time I've been playing it there have already been two small patches for it. If you're a fan of mystery games, particularly of the Ace Attorney variety, this is a pretty easy purchase overall. It has enough original elements to keep veterans of the genre on their talons, while providing more of the mysteries that they love.

With the new update bringing ending 4-C, I can finally recommend this game with good conscience. Not that the game wasn't good before, but it was imcomplete prior to the update, which is worth mentioning.

For example, there are branching paths (you can get three major endings in fact), and it is possible to fail cases and continue the game with your failure affecting various portions. Investigation segments are also a lot of fun due to having to choose carefully on where you choose to investigate. Overall, I highly recommend this game, especially to fans of the Ace Attorney series.

reviewText:
I want to start by saying that I love the visual style of this game, and it got me into playing an attorney game even though I'd never played one before. The writing is cute and engaging, and the characters can be a lot of fun.

But on the whole, I've found the game disappointingly buggy. Sometimes it's just that the dialogue options haven't been thought through properly (for instance, if you need to choose a character from the list of characters you know to accuse of something or to ask about, and you choose the wrong person for the storyline, the characters will say something like 'Who is that person?' even if it was a friend of theirs, which makes things very confusing for the player, since you start worrying you pressed the wrong button or something). Once, in Act 3, I asked about an unimportant piece of data and midway through discussing it the dialogue skipped back to a previous conversation on a different subject.

Sometimes the bugs are bigger. It's already been noted that depending on how you play through, Act 4 may not be accessible to you at all. I made a mistake in Act 3 and Act 4 isn't accessible to me, so I went back to play from Act 2, but when I try to load Day 1 of Act 2, it bugs out and gives me an illustration, but no characters or dialogue and I can't move forward. I feel that this game has a pretty hefty price for mostly text-based gameplay if it's going to have this many game-halting problems with it. It's not just the unfinished Act 4, there are a number of serious and confusing problems that really affect the experience or sometimes terminate it altogether. Especially if the game is going to be so unforgiving (going to a location that I had a lead for a day earlier than I was apparently supposed to caused me to fail my goal in Act 2), and going to halt your progress if you make certain decisions, then it really needs to be able to reload properly from previous days.

I think this game could be really great, but it's lacking polish and completion in several serious areas, so at the moment I don't think it can be said to be worth $15 or even $13.

My playtime is accurate at 4.7 hours. I consider my playtime to be around average. I didn't scrounge for every single piece of dialogue, but I also had a slightly higher reading pace. If you have difficulties with logic puzzle games, this may be a bit longer as I think I figured out necessary actions fairly quickly.This will bring the total playtime to around 5 hours when the last route releases. I would consider that a respectable amount for the price point.

Music:
The music for the game is very solid. The soundtrack brings appropriate ambiance that fits both the story's setting of old France and it plays to the situation at hand. I was never jarred by off-putting choices of music at any point. My only criticism of the music is there wasn't any that felt catchy or memorable enough. I have no urge to open up the soundtrack to just listen to a particular song.

Visuals:
The visuals speak for themselves. Absolutely stunning and unique. From the backgrounds to the character art, the game looks great and I find myself eager to explore new zones just to see what they look like. Nothing to say here but praise. Great work.

Writing:
Here's where the game gets really juicy. The game accomplishes what it tries to do perfectly. The humor in the game goes well beyond just puns and animal jokes. Exclamatory remarks, running jokes, and wordplay are all done with great timing and execution.

The characters themselves are indeed memorable and unique. No one felt like a copy of each other or even as adhering to an established character archetype. You will undoubtedly find a favorite among the cast. The character development is also quite nice as well, flowing naturally and without feeling forced.

The story is quite engaging and progresses. Your choices do matter and the chapters flow into one another, not standalone episodes. You follow the main character's story and see how far they will go. The conflicting ideologies presented in the game are quite well done. Both sides are presented fairly, neither being demonized, and you get to see some of the humanity behind each train of thought. I really love how they did this and I appreciate the writer's efforts.


Gameplay:
It's inevitable to talk about this game without talking about a certain other series. However, I wouldn't go so far as to say took mechanics and ideas, but it feels more like a love letter to a beloved memory. The gameplay is very good and separated into 2 main sections: trials and exploration. You explore, get evidence, and meet people to prepare for the upcoming trials. Your success in exploring will carry you through the trial. The game presents a very nice tutorial section that exposes you to all the mechanics before getting more and more complex in a very natural way. I would liken this to a logic puzzle, where common sense and intuition rule and will be your friend. I personally enjoyed the gameplay very much, and you probably will too if you're even just looking into the game to see what it's about. I will say, it will take more than one playthrough and some testing to try and get all the endings.


Closing remarks:
If the price point puts you off, don't worry about it. The game is worth the money and you're supporting the devs and their hard work. They need to eat too.

The game is also still being polished. During my first playthrough, I encountered a few bugs, but those were quickly patched out. The devs are responsive and looking to create a great experience.

The writing, gameplay, and art of the game are all astounding and some of the best I've seen out of a project like this.

I look forward to the game's success, the future works of the devs, and maybe even a sequel if they're so kind.

reviewText:
Keep in mind, I did not experience the unfinished ending.  So I may not be as helpful as others.

A video of this piece can be found here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QSiIYKuvGL4&feature=youtu.be

Aviary Attorney unfolds in 19th century France, where an attorney named Jayjay Falcon and his petite assistant Sparrowson defend many anthropomorphic animals in the courtroom.  Or as Sparrowson abrasively states, “help people get away with criminal acts”.  The duo investigate crime scenes and testimonies to craft a repertoire of evidence to defend their client.  And ultimately find the truth behind every illusive crime.

The writing is impeccable in Aviary Attorney.  It retains all the wit and courtroom drama of Ace Attorney with the banter of Hatoful Boyfriend.  Every joke had near flawless comedic timing and even after the 20th horse pun I was still in stitches.  The different acts follow different cases, and can each be played in 2-3 hours easily.  Through every character there’s a voice that resonates when reading their dialogue, proving that the written word in visual novels can still resonate even without voice acting.

Aviary Attorney retains the artistic integrity of caricature artist, Jean Ignace Isidore Gérard Grandville.  Rather than the colorful hyper-realism of Hatoful Boyfriend, the artstyle in Aviary Attorney is predominantly weathered yellow backdrops with hand drawn character models overlayed.  If you’ve ever played Phoenix Wright, the eccentric character models may pop into mind.  Aviary Attorney takes inspiration with this.  And combined with the anthropomorphic elements, it creates a great composition of colorful characters, even though it’s pastels are black and white.

The music in Aviary Attorney is composed by French 19th century artist Camille Saint-Saëns, and its authenticity really brings the world to life.  With every orchestration reflecting the bourgeoisie atmosphere of early France.  It’s a very great and smart decision to use pieces of the era instead of attempting to replicate the early art in an OST.

As a Visual novel, Aviary Attorney has very minimal gameplay besides menu navigations and pursuing through text. However, unlike most visual novels.  Aviary Attorney takes inspiration from one of the most renown visual novels in gaming history.  The GBA and DS classics, Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney (which surprisingly didn’t feature a feathered protagonist) from Capcom.  Aviary Attorney takes the formula of that first game, where after an introduction to the murder case you interview witnesses and examine crime scenes to gather crucial evidence.  Following your investigations, it’s off to the courtroom.  Where you must use aforementioned evidence to seduce the jury to your side.  By combing over witness statements and contradicting affidavits with evidence you will gain the jury’s mindshare, but by wasting their time you lose their enthusiasm with the person you’re defending.  Getting over each obstacle and test with minimal dissatisfaction from the jury, will result in the real murderer revealing himself and your client will be saved from the guilty verdict.

A hefty 25 hour game with multiple endings, Aviary Attorney fully justifies it’s 15 dollar price tag.  I’m not a big fan of Visual Novels, but Aviary Attorney is a great lampoon of the Ace Attorney formula with its interactivity.  This isn’t to say that Aviary Attorney is a bad Visual Novel, the writing is astonishing and comedic.  While France has been depicted in Assassin’s Creed, the music and art in Aviary Attorney bring the place and period to life in a way that is significantly pure.  The attention to detail the folks at Sketchy Logic have for the time period doubles in the respect they have for the history and time period.  Aviary Attorney is a compilation of great writing, art, music, and characters.  And one of 2015’s most significant surprises.

reviewText:
Comparisons to Ace Attorney are inevitible, as they're intentionally self-evoked here, but Aviary Attorney does have more than enough to it that makes it a much different experience.

For one, the game is more about breadth than depth. The main storyline only took me around 4 hours to complete, but my playtime double going through the game again to see alternate paths and the other two endings. Each trial has multiple outcomes that can affect the story in different ways ranging from a few small details to three distinct endings. The game has a lot more replayability to it than the linear Ace Attorney games, and that's not a knock against Ace Attorney either, the linearity allows the game to provide a much more in-depth story.

That's not to say the story in Aviary Attorney is lacking; far from it. What starts off as a silly bird-lawyering game escalates into a turbulent tale of rebellion and violence, with three potential outcomes. The game is far darker than Ace Attorney ever gets, and the scope of your actions is far more reaching than the relatively minimal stakes the Ace Attorney series sticks to. There's a variety of characters with interesting personality quirks and a good dose of humor as well, the game can still be fairly lighthearted at times, but going in expecting something as over-the-top silly as Ace Attorney would be a mistake.

The gameplay also differs a fair bit. For one, it's much more fast-paced. Investigations are done a day at a time, and you have a limited time to get everything done that you need done, making it possible to fail any trial if you don't have proper evidence (or simply present the wrong evidence too many times). The first case is fairly trivial to complete, but it's possible to miss some crucial details in the second case and the third case is actually quite strict as far as what you need to do to ensure a successful trial, while giving you more options than you'll know what to do with. There's a bit of a trial-and-error element but when you have a sense of what you're missing or what you did wrong, it's not too hard to put the pieces together and have a perfect case after only a replay or two. And replays can be done fairly quick as the text is all fast to skip.

If I were to have any real problems with the game, it would mostly come down to three issues. First, path 4A is a bit... awful, storywise. It forces one of the main characters way out of character to push an overly dramatic and hard to take seriously storyline, though since the player intentionally has to initiate this ending, perhaps it was done on purpose? reviewText:
Taken by itself, this game is alright.  Stick with me, there's more to this, or this would be a thumbs-up.

There's a good narrative, but the gameplay suffers for it.  The gameplay is immaterial for the first half of the game; while it's true that winning or losing a trial affects the game, it's a cosmetic difference in the end.  Nothing actually changes, you're not locked into or out of any ending.  There's a lot of promise here, with the time passing mechanic, the ability to miss evidence and lose lose trials and continue, and having a jury to convince, but the game shifts narrative gears after two cases and that opportunity is squandered.

My other big complaint is that the game deliberately attempts to evoke Ace Attorney, and does a poor job in practice.  The gameplay is incredibly shallow; you never have more than a couple handfuls of evidence, and the contradictions should be incredibly easy to spot for any veteran of the series.  The most likely thing to trip you up is the time mechanic.  It's also short.  I've got 4.4 hours on record; that's how long it takes to beat the game and get every ending.

Truth be told, this would probably be better without what feels like a token amount of gameplay.  The narrative is interesting, and if you're looking for a good short story you could do worse.  However, you will likely leave very disappointed if you're looking for gameplay of Ace Attorney caliber, as I was, which is why this is getting a negative review.

reviewText:
A lighthearted delight for fans of handsome birds and courtroom dramas alike. While I've never played the Ace Attorney games myself, I'm told this one draws a lot from those, with its own twists on the formula. You gather evidence through interviews and exploration of the crime scene and other places, stretching the role of what a defence attorney really does, and then you'll be given the chance to use that evidence against in the courtroom during cross-examinations by clicking on the part of a witness' statement you're able to contradict. It's simple, and not especially difficult, but it's fun and satisfying to work out and the developing storylines are entertaining and well-written, even if they can be predictable at times.

It's all just so irresistibly charming, with a witty sense of humour and a colourful cast of characters. The art style, which literally just involves pasting animal heads onto 1800's paintings, looks sharp and distinct and really helps you immerse yourself in this seemingly alternate-history 1840's France. The main cast makes for a memorable pair, and I was frankly sad to have to see them go when I finished up the game. Though it's all over pretty fast, it's a satisfying journey and can end in multiple ways, with three entirely distinct final chapters depending on your choices in the third act, all of which can come to different conclusions.

With the multiple finales to be explored, there's actually a pretty good amount of content here, even if I found some of the finales more interesting than others. One was just what I wanted, the other was surprisingly good even if it started out a bit grim, and the third just seemed a little too dark and out of tone with the rest of the game. Despite that, they were all fun to explore and worth playing through, even if sometimes their endings felt a bit abrupt.

I really can't think of anything I disliked about this one, other than it being a bit short and sometimes not entirely clear where you should go to find your clues. It's possible to miss important pieces of evidence by failing to visit the places you can find them or screwing something up when you get there, and if you do manage to fail a case, the story continues on rather than making you replay it, which is good but I can imagine would be a lot less satisfying an experience. Though it might be funny to play it again and fail the early cases on purpose just to see what happens.

If you're a fan of visual novel kinds of things, and like murder mysteries and courtroom antics, then I hope you'll enjoy this one as much as I did.

Okay, so this is probably my first actual review of a game. I'm writing this to show my genuine appreciation for this lovely piece of work.

And what a piece of work it is. I expected it to just be a jokey game full of puns and without anything big beyond the gimmick of animal people and avian lawyers. If you decide to buy and play it, you might expect Avian Attorney to be just that based on the first five, maybe ten minutes of play. I - and you, if you follow my train of thought - could not be more wrong. I won't go into details to avoid spoiling parts of the game, but it utterly gripped me.

The characters you're supposed to like are likeable, the characters you ought to hate make themselves out to be absolute scum of the earth based on their in-game actions. It's all very believable as well, the plot and subplots seamlessly and smoothly hurry onward while you frantically make sense of courtroom law and procedure.

The game will last you about five hours if you do some reloading and read most of the text. More if you explore every path (I can recommend trying all three endings, they're amazing and very different from one another), less if you skip through it (don't). Expect to play it in one or two sittings, it's very hard to put the game down.

If a sequel or some other similar game by this studio appears I'm buying it as soon as possible. It's just quality, dammit.

Aviary Attorney is a game made in the style of Ace Attorney, featuring woodcut art, a pleasant, classical soundtrack, and colorful animal characters.

Its beautiful woodcut art-style lends characters an immediate visual flair and POP. Coupled with the solid writing and at least one or two interesting twists thus far - I've finished the first act - I can happily say it is at least equal with the more famous Lawyer Game's writing.

Much like Ace Attorney, you follow an Attorney - here, one JJ Falcon - and his Assistant - Sparrowson -. The two have a delightful dynamic, and descriptions for items and the locations you find are, while punny, quite delightful.

If you've ever played an Ace Attorney game, you should know what to expect; you go to locations, examine specific items - which are highlighted for you, to prevent tedious pixelhunting - and, later on, use those items and your findings in trials, to prove your points and make objections.

It's not wholly identical to Ace Attorney, however. Going to certain locations takes up a day's time, and it is possible to lose favor with the jury by needlessly pressing on witness statements.  These statements have, thus far tended more towards being clear, concise pieces of logic; a vital necessity given the way the game works.

In short, if you're a fan of the Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney series, you owe it to yourself to pick up Aviary Attorney.

It is 1848, Paris. Even in the city of lights darkness still festers. But there are those who stand against the rising tide of evil. Foremost amongst these bastions of hope is one man. Well okay maybe he isn't really up there in the scheme of things. And maybe he isn't technically a man, he's a falcon. But nonetheless he stands to see justice prevails in the heart of revolution.

Aviary Attorney is one of those games looks interesting but maybe you don't expect that much from.  However I'm very pleased to say that it's maybe one of the biggest surprise delights I've had all year.  The game play for Aviary Attorney falls somewhere in between Hatoful Boyfriend and Phoenix Wright. You must traipse through the streets of Paris searching for clues and evidence in order to prevail at court and let the truth out.

However you mustn't let the rather simple outward appearance of the game's mechanics take your guard down. What seems like a straight forward search for the key piece of evidence and then compare it to the correct bit of testimony at court at first quickly reveals itself to be a much more complex and far darker plot. For perhaps obvious reasons I shan't go into any detail but suffice to say that there are more twists and turns in this plot than a particularly rotated piece of Fussili.

Your own personal detective skills are tested as you must choose which leads to follow and which to drop, if pushing a potential witness will give you that vital information or push them away and choosing which location will give you valuable evidence. The game has you on a ticking clock meaning that the decisions that you make have real weight and it has no qualms about letting you miss vital bits of evidence that may prove your downfall in court. You are also limited in funds, some task will require that you acquire items or 'persuade' somebody a few franks changing wings can make this all the easier. More than once you know that there is some kind of connection but with only a limited amount of time and resources you simply cannot secure the evidence you require.

Aviary Attorney smashed my expectations. The writing is superbly witty and hilarious without relying on bird puns (though there are still of few of those for good measure) with gameplay that is far more complex than it might at first appear. The soundtracks pretty good too. The story is a great foray into trying to uphold justice against whatever force may try to stop you. Even the populous that you try to protect. After all, this is Paris. A revolution is never far away.

I thoroughly recommend this game - it would not be a stretch to say that this has been the best money I have spent on Steam this year!

In it, you play the role of JayJay Falcon,a somewhat unsuccessful defense attorney who finds himself in the employ of a menagerie of strange clients and you will need to call upon the efforts of your tireless assistant Sparrowson and your own critical-thinking skills in order to win each trial.

reviewText:
A very charming take on the Ace Attorney-style gameplay. With a refreshing, underused setting of 19-th century France, beautiful artwork by J. J. Grandsville, and a musical score that ranges from whimsicall to outright epic, Aviary Attorney turns into an experience thatI had no idea that I had wanted previously.

For those who aren't familiar with the Ace Attorney-style detective games, here's a brief introduction: The main characters ar edefense atorneys, who have a new case brought upon them with each chapter. In the alloted days leading up to the trial, they must travel about the city in search of evidence so that their defendant may walk free from impending incarceration. The unique gameplay element that Aviary Attorney introduces is the ability to fail a case and have the story progress in spite of it. Because of this, the game allows you to re-load any given day within a chapter so the player may make new decisions and achieve a different outcome. This is really handy, considering that there are several subplots that can develop differently over the course of the first three chapters.

One of my favorite additions this game brings to the genre is its sense of scale. Aviary Attorney takes place in a society on the cusp of revolution. The meta-narrative of the game is presented not only in some of the major cases, but also in optional cutscenes that not only flesh out the world, but do so in a manner that helps present the story in a manner akin to a noir television serial.
Within the three possible endings you can achieve, it's very interesting to see how our characters will eveolve along with the plot. There's welcome character growth within each route that builds on previous cases in a different way. It's definitely one of the best introductions of consequence in a murder-mystery game.

This game is definitely worth it's price if you're itching for a new murder mystery series to explore.With the added ability to fail a given trial and have the story go on despite it, the game's ability to re-load any individual day of a case allows for an unexpected ammount of replayability. Fans of mystery novels, the French revolutionary period, and witty humor should definitely crack this one open!

reviewText:
Let's get the elephant in the room out of the way first. Yes, one of the variants of the final chapter is missing from the game at the time of writing. But it will probably be back in fairly soon and you don't have to pay for it, so I don't really see the issue. Also, you only get the particular version of the chapter if you ♥♥♥♥ up the previous one. So, uh, don't do that, I guess.

Speaking of elephants in rooms, you may have noticed that all of the characters are animals. The art style is actually one of the game's strongest points. And I don't say that often. The fact that they're animals is hardly important to the plot, beyond a few puns and maybe cats clawing people to death. It's a neat way of having all the characters be visually distinct without resorting to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ anime drawings. And despite the game being a visual novel, there are quite a few charming little animations to give things a bit more character.

The gameplay is pretty inventive, but sadly underutilised. It's like Ace Attorney, unsurprisingly. There's an investigation phase, where you talk to witnesses and look for clues, and then the trial phase, where you present evidence to contradict the witness' testimony. It's all very talky. The key difference with Aviary Attorney is the time limit during the investigation phase. Each place you investigate will take you a full day, and you have only a limited time before the trial starts. If you faff about going to the same locations too many times, or in the wrong order, you might not have all the clues ready for the trial. Which means you might not get the best possible ending.

This is something a lot of mystery games lack- an actual failure state. Too many allow you to click on everything until you find the solution. It's neat that the game doesn't patronise me by making the solution too obvious.

It's not all perfect though. I found the game to be pretty easy- I got the best ending for every case on my first try. I mean, it probably helps that I've played Ace Attorney and Danganronpa before, but even if you haven't, the game heavily hints at where to go next during the investigation phase, and the trial phase usually has fairly obvious contradictions. If you don't know what to do during the trial, just press every statement. Eventually, someone will say something like I bet you can't prove that the witness owns a massive blood stained knife"

reviewText:
A game that takes heavy inspirations from the famed Ace Attourney series. If you have played Ace Attourney games Ill happily recommend this to you. It has the similar charm and wit, although unlike Ace Attourney you seem to actualy have a time limit. And a lawyer who actualy seems to know about court etiquette and rules.

Also the investigation parts wandering around Paris provide a refressing chance to screw up. You could simply use too many days simply playing Blackjack in the tavern. Or maybe you missclicked and ended the investigation inside your current location.

Heres a quick summary of the positives and negatives

+ Wonderful artstyle.
Jean Jaques Grandevilles 18th century art comes alive and the animal characters fit the story.

+ Music is fantastic.
Classical music fiths the 18th century like chocolate on a croissant

+The story is intriguing.
The different cases in the game provide decent variety in terms of turns and events. The game managed to even surprise me when I was in a too Ace Attourney way of thinking.

-The game is woefully short.
I completed my first playthrough in 5.6 hours according to steam. Even that time had few breaks where the game was left running. This is the greatest negative to the game. As a single case in later Ace Attourney games could easily last that amount of time by itself. Provided you take your time.

-The ending was a bit....anti climactic.
In the 4th case I was in the B route. And it left me...Wanting more. Or a more epic conclusion.

These negatives dont outright ruin the game. But you should keep them in mind still. Nevertheless I enjoyed my time with JayJay and Sparrowson and I am looking forward to any possible continuation of their story. Or maybe another characters story inside the Aviary Attourney universe.

reviewText:
If you like Ace Attorney then you have come to the right place.

The Writing is on par and in many cases better than Ace Attorney and better than the vast majority of Visual Novels on Steam and thats not an exaggeration. The jokes and puns are spot on and don't seem contrived. The dialogue fits each character well. Sparrowson is a riot and is the funny guy to Falcon's straght man and they compliment each other much like Sherlock Holmes and Watson do. Your choices have meaning though what meaning may not be readily apparent until the consequences are dropped on you. The court cases themselves are well done and reward you for paying attention and punishes you for blindly reaching.

The Art is exactly how it appears. The good thing is the characters are animated well, its not overdone but its not just static images so it makes the dialogue and art seem much more realistic. The visual effects following dramatic scenes are especially poignant. The fact that the characters are animals is not really commented on aside from puns but it helps give each character a unique appearance. There is a surprisingly large cast and each character including ones that get only one or two lines is lovingly drawn and animated.

The Sound direction is spot on as well. While the soundtrack is open sourced and public domain, they fit the associating characters so perfectly I have to give a personal shoutout to whoever took the time to match them up so nicely. Otherwise the sounds are actually quite miniaml and lends itself well to the art and storytelling.

There are a few odd bugs that aren't readily apparent but they have been speedy in their updates thus far.

---

Bottom Line is this is a great game and for the surprisingly low price of $14.99 its a steal. I got it on sale but I feel as though had I paid full price I would still feel satisfied with the content I got for thr price. I wish I had backed their crowdfunding and will probably help fund their next game should they choose to make one. I don't usually give such high praise but this game managed to hit all the right notes for me. To give it a number I would say 9/10. 9.5/10 when the bugs are ironed out. In my Top 5 of favorite VNs.

reviewText:
An excellent, excellent game.  I bought it expecting it to be a humorous homage to the Phoenix Wright franchise, but I was happily mistaken: this game stands perfectly fine on its own two bird-feet.

The art and animation are clean and pleasant to look at, and not overly complicated, like a visual novel.  The writing was also nice, ranging from bad puns to interesting (if slightly heavy-handed, but I gave this a pass considering the time period) social commentary.  In fact, my only regret about this game is that there isn't more content, though it's implied that there's more coming soon!

A quick note: Un-learn your Ace Attorney habits.  The game does not grind to a stop while you collect every bit of evidence you need, so if you're not careful you can end up going into a trial without important information or evidence.  Fortunately, the game is still forgiving, and you are able to go back and re-peat specific days to get whatever it was you forgot.  There's also more than one solution to a puzzle, and multiple endings!

reviewText:
A wonderful variant on the tried-and-true Ace Attorney style.

Unlike the AA games, Aviary Attorney has a much stronger emphasis on the investigation part of the game, while the court sections are rather brief, but both are handled well. There's a push for greater realism in the court part of the game: while you can do the whole Phoenix Wright thing and find the real criminal and force him to confess in court, it's not always a requirement for a not guilty verdict. Simply demonstrating reasonable doubt IS sufficient.

It's also notable that the investigation sections have an action limit: going to a location to investigate it takes a day, and wasting time can mean the difference between mere acquittal and catching the real culprit -- or even outright failure -- since the trials are on fixed days that can't be moved.

But failure actually isn't the end in Aviary Attorney. The game has multiple possible endings, and failing cases can be necessary for some. In this way, the way you play the game determines not only the outcome, but also the tone of the game itself: idealistic play will result in an idealistic game, cynical play will result in a cynical game, and wacky Ace Attorney play can result in a wacky Ace Attorney game.

I laughed, I cried, I got punched by a lion. 9/10, could use meatier trial sections but great game nonetheless.

The storylines that were finished that is... sadly when you achieve one of the main story branches it states that the path is not yet finished and you have to step back a few days and try a different course of action. You travel around Paris in order to collect evidence and defend your client. There are several different locations you can travel to but traveling to most locations takes a whole day and you only have a certain amount of days before you must appear in court. This puts contraints on what you can do which makes matters seem more pressing. Avian Attorney really pushes you to actually investigate rather than blow money gambling on black jack (which is totally an option). the nice thing is if you missed a crucial piece of evidence you can always step back a day to get the ending you want. as I mentioned above the dialogue is also well written. There are so many different approaches you can take to obtain different forms of evidence or get past obstacles. will you bribe them or persuade them or just threaten to beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of them? the shear variety of choice within what is a relatively short storyline is the main draw for this game, well.. that and the glorious amount of Bird puns. all-in-all I give the game an 8/10 purely for being unfinished and me wanting even more of it! Although seemingly a simple novelty game at first sight Avian Attorney proves itself to be a fun and interesting ride for those who enjoy investigative games.  A tip though, if you find yourself stumped? just WING it. ha ha.. get it... Ill show myself out...

There are some significant and insignificant bugs and typos at the time of this writing (December 27th, 2015), but the package as a whole is more than good enough for me to forgive some rough edges. It’s a visual novel about lawyers practicing in 19th Century France, except everyone is a creature from the illustrations of 19th Century satirist J. J. Grandville, set to music by the romantic era composer Camille Saint-Saëns.

The whole thing has a very Hatoful Boyfriend kind of feel to it, and not just because of the static images or the birds: this is a game that has a completely ridiculous premise and uses that to draw the player in to a grim tale of political strife, asking questions about justice and revenge. Parts of it seem to be direct responses to Ace Attorney scenes, too - a lot of Ace Attorney moments get flipped on their heads here.

That’s not to say it isn’t really funny when it wants to be - it’s freaking hilarious when it feels like it! That’s another thing that feels really Hatoful Boyfriend about the whole proceeding, but it’s certainly its own thing, and it got its talons in me really deep. Can’t wait for the third ending to get fixed!

reviewText:
Witty, well-written, and managing to throw in some twists and turns, I would definitely recommend Aviary Attorney to anyone looking for a narrative-driven game!
It plays very similarly to the Ace Attorney games, you start by being given a case by a (possibly) falsely accused individual. After this, you explore locales related to the crime, collecting evidence and testimony. Once that's done, you go to the courtroom and try to outwit the prosecutor by cross-examining witness testimonies with evidence.
What sets this apart from the Ace Attorney series has to be the way that decisions make the game play out. A poorly worded sentence or illegally acquired evidence can bar you from a useful piece of information for the trial. Does this change the course of the trial? I'm not entirely sure, even after the first case, I want to go in for another go to get those pieces of evidence I couldn't get before.
The game gives off a great atmosphere. The art is superb and very reminiscent of Victorian-style ink drawings. Character portraits will move around the screen in conjunction with actual movement, which on paper sounds small, but in a visual novel-style game it helps to immerse you in what the characters are doing.
The writing is superb. There are some laugh-out-loud funny moments in here, which is an achievement in itself.
To be honest, I bought this game on a whim, being a bit of an avian fanatic. But I was not disappointed in what I got from this, and I have yet to play the full game, even.

EDIT:
I guess if there were one thing to comment on right now, the game doesn't seem to be 100% finished at this time. I was playing through part three and got to a certain point, and I'm guessing it's just the path that I was sent through based on my actions, but after I hit a certain point I was given a screen telling me to check back in a couple of days after an update or to go back and try to go for a different ending. reviewText:
Aviary Attorney was one of the standout games of my alcohol fuelled Steam sale binge. You take on the role of JayJay Falcon, Paris' finest bird defence lawyer as he investigates crimes, interviews witnesses, assembles cases and proves his clients innocence. Fans of the Ace Attorney games will be right at home with the gameplay, but be warned if you fail a case you carry on regardless, albeit in a more morose mood than before. Time waits for no man, and neither does Aviary Attorney, if you failed to pick up the crucial piece of evidence then you will be punished for it later. The story changes depending on your actions, a refreshing change from chronically linear games that inspired it.


The aesthetics of the game are a lovingly curated experience, the character art is from J.J. Grandville’s “The Public and Private Life of Animals”, the backgrounds and objects are from other period books, and even the font is old! The attention to detail is staggering, not a single piece looks out of place. Combine this with a lovely soundtrack comprised of music by romantic-era composer Camille Saint-Saëns and you have a gorgeous game straight out of 1840’s Paris.


Hilarious to a fault when it wants to be and surprisingly dark when it needs to, you are playing a tense, pre-revolution Paris after all. If you need more courtroom style games in your life, this is certainly a good place to start.

However, if you are turned off by Aviary Attorney's shortness and easy difficulty you may want to wait and pick it up on sale.

Pros:
+ The story is well crafted and entertaining, with three incredibly varied endings.
+ The writing is witty and well done.
+ The visuals and sound are beautiful.
+ An incredible cast of characters.
+ The courtroom and crime scene investigation gameplay is just as fun as the Ace Attorney series.

Cons:
- The game is short. It took me only 4 hours on my first playthrough and 6 hours to see every ending.
- There is little replay value after completing all endings, save to make different choices for a few minor plot changes.
- Easy courtroom and investigation puzzles. I had no problem procuring all necessary evidence on my first playthrough and faltered only once or twice in presenting wrong evidence.

Recommended

Rating: 8/10
